newsitem.title: UK: Analysts douse Vodafone, C&W bid talk.
newsitem.headline: Analysts douse Vodafone, C&W bid talk.

text.p: London telecoms analysts on Monday dismissed speculation that British telecoms groups Vodafone and Cable and Wireless might attract a bid in the wake of British Telecommunications' $20 billion merger with MCI.
Vodafone and Cable and Wireless opened sharply higher on Monday amid hopes that BT's deal with MCI, the second biggest U.S. carrier, might prod U.S. telecoms giant AT&T into seeking a similar deal.
While some analysts said Vodafone may become a future bid target, few thought Cable and Wireless would attract a takeover after merger talks with BT failed six months ago.
"I'm amazed that people are still talking about Cable and Wireless being bid for," said one analyst who declined to be named. "It has been demonstrated by BT that C&W is bid proof."

The regulatory uncertainties, difficulties in valueing C&W and its 57.5 percent stake in Hong Kong Telecommunications -- as well as the need, under Hong Kong law, to buy out the balance of Hong Kong Telecom, combined to make a bitter pill for any potential bidder, analysts said.
"AT&T may be deemed big enough but they have moved horribly slowly of late," said an analyst at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell.
"To do something all of a sudden would be out of character."

Analysts said that mobile telephone market leader Vodafone, which held most of its gains and was trading at 245, a rise of 8.5 pence by 1415 GMT, was undervalued in the face of an aceleration in the UK mobile telephone market and its new product range.
"This deal does help to underpin Vodafone's international valuation," said one analyst who declined to be named, adding that the group may form an alliance with another international firm.
Vodafone is attractive because it provides local access via its mobile network without the need of spending vast quantities of money building trenches.

"We do belive Vodafone's value is underpinned by the BT/MCI developments and there might be more development in the near term. What I don't believe we'll see, is AT&T coming in to make a bid," he said.
By 1430 GMT, Cable and Wireless' shares had lost earlier gains and were trading at 487.5 pence, a loss of two pence.
